naics_industry_sector: Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation (71)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to construct a mass timber science annex addition to the Fairbanks Museum and Planetarium in St. Johnsbury, Vermont. The project includes construction of a 6,153 square foot addition as well as renovation of 1,584 square feet in the museums historic 1891 building. The three-story addition contains classroom and exhibit space, a stair tower, elevator, and four restrooms. The ground floor and balcony levels will contain Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) exhibits, while the plaza level will add classroom and reception space for the Community College of Vermonts St. Johnsbury site. The addition will be fully accessible and will make the balcony of the historic building partially accessible. As Vermonts first mass timber project, construction will provide workforce development and support the forestry industry in the northeastern U.S. The new hands-on STEM activities will complement the museums "look, dont touch" exhibits from the museums inception. The colleges relocation of its St. Johnsbury site to the museum will also increase visitation to the space. Additional funding for the project comes from the Northern Borders Regional Commission, several corporate and private foundations, and individual contributions to the museums Inspire Campaign.

naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will help purchase a sterilizer machine for the Northeastern Vermont Regional Hospital in St. Johnsbury, Vt. Grant funds will be used to purchase a large, 48-inch steam sterilizer for use in the operating room. The new sterilizer will replace two smaller ones that are well past their useful life. Additionally, it will accommodate the larger surgical tools required for hip and knee procedures. Replacing the outdated machines will reduce servicing costs, as the older machines require more frequent maintenance, allowing the hospital to channel resources to other places where they are needed to improve patient care. The hospital budgets for some equipment replacement each year, but increased spending during the pandemic for related equipment and supplies has left that funding source short. Beyond surgical services, the hospitals sterilizers are used for tools from many departments inside the hospital and for four community clinics associated with the hospital. An applicant contribution of $55,254 will provide additional funding for this project.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase equipment, including a pickup truck with a customized vacuum pump and lift gate, storage tanks, office and lab furniture, safety equipment for the lab areas, and other office and lab equipment as needed to support the activities of Rich Earth Institute, Inc.s research facility in Brattleboro, VT. Rich Earth Institute is a groundbreaking non-profit that engages in research, education and technological innovation to advance the use of human waste as a resource and has recently been expanding their programs. Their unique work benefits the community in two important areas: improving water quality and supporting local farms. The Institute currently provides regular urine collection and recycling services to approximately 200 people throughout Windham County, representing approximately 95 households, and will soon include several public and business facilities that are installing urine diverting toilet fixtures. Their program keeps urine out of the wastewater stream, which reduces the amount of damaging nutrient pollution flowing into groundwater and surface waters. The urine is processed into a sanitized liquid fertilizer product, which is distributed to local farmers for growing hay. Currently over 10,000 gallons of urine is processed per year, providing four farms with fertilizer, and with recent grants five additional farmer partners will be added. Rich Earth Institute has also been able to expand their staff team and internship programs and has plans to build a new collection depot in Rockingham within the year. Although currently assisting local farmers, the long-term impacts of Rich Earth Institutes work may be far reaching for the agricultural sector as well as addressing pollution issues. The equipment they are able to purchase with this grant will help support the expanding role Rich Earth Institutes research facility in Brattleboro.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to improve the waste water system in Vergennes, Vermont, including the waste water treatment facility and three sewer line segments. The waste water treatment facility, built in 1980, needs improvements to address effluent permit requirements, age related needs, redundancy requirements, and site constraints. Converting to sequencing batch reactors (SBRs), decommissioning the lagoons, upgrading processing buildings, improving the electrical systems including the installation of a backup generator, upgraded lighting to LED with automatic controls, and the installation of sensor hardware and software monitoring systems are planned. Three sewer segments of approximately 1 mile will be replaced to address the inflow and infiltration issues that are a pollution and health issue. This project is a segment of an overall $25 million project addressing pollution overflow into the Potash Brook and then Otter Creek, discharges that adversely affect the quality of waters of the State and create public health concerns for the over 2,200 users of the system. These overflows are predicted to increase with climate change and associated large storm and flooding events. The other segments of the overall project will address force main redundancy, upgrading a pump station, and replacement of two additional sewer line segments.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to provide Little Rivers Health Care Inc. (LRHC) with funds to take on an ambitious renovation and expansion project at its Wells River clinic. LRHC provides comprehensive integrated primary-care services to the residents of Bradford, East Corinth, Wells River and more recently, Newbury, Vermont. The Wells River clinic operates out of a centuries-old barn and is in dire need of renovation to better meet the needs of their patients, especially in light of healthcare gaps laid bare by the COVID-19 pandemic.Improvements will include additional exam rooms, health offices, care team support spaces, a waiting room, work reception area, bathrooms and fire safety compliance work. The project will accommodate additional clinicians and increase access to primary care in economically disadvantaged areas severely impacted by the pandemic, as evidenced by sharp increases in demand for medicinal, behavioral and mental-health care. Services like family medicine, pediatrics, obstetrics, counseling, psychiatric care, substance-use disorder treatment, oral health services, chronic care management, care coordination, and migrant farmworker outreach will all be enhanced with physical assets better aligned with their primary purpose.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to upgrade the heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) system at the town of Randolph Kimball Library. Heating and cooling upgrades at the library have been made over the years but were piecemeal. These improvements did not fully address overall air quality, comfort for staff and patrons, and energy efficiency. The greatest deficit was the lack of mechanical ventilation in the building. This was a contributing factor leading to closures during several phases of the COVID-19 pandemic. The improvements to the library will include replacement of the aged central air conditioning that serves the main level with ducted cold-climate heat pumps with integrated energy recovery ventilation. The fiscal year 2022 library HVAC upgrades will lead to improved air quality in the facility and reduce the librarys full reliance on fossil fuel as a primary heating source. This will reduce energy costs as well as reduce carbon emissions, given less oil will be used as a heating fuel due to the operations of heat pump and mechanical recovery systems.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to expand and modernize Craftsbury Community Care Centers (CCCC) kitchen. CCCC is located in Craftsbury, Vermont in the Northeast Kingdom and is a 24-unit full service live in residential facility. The CCCC kitchen is also used to prepare meals on selected days of the week for distribution in cooperation with the Meals on Wheels program. The facility will be expanding 204 square feet and modernizing several critical equipment items to improve food-service operations. The current kitchen configuration is an original set-up installed 25 years ago. It became evident during the COVID-19 pandemic extra kitchen space, as well as improvements to kitchen equipment, was needed. The expanded and renovated space will allow for installation of a new freezer, walk-in cooler and upgrades to sinks, food storage areas, kitchen lighting, flooring and ventilation systems. This equipment will allow the fire department to maintain communications while enroute to calls via fire engine or airboat, as well as fit up the equipment inventory from eight to 24 portable radios so each firefighter can carry a radio. The repeaters will enhance signals to improve reliability where signal reception is spotty. The city has experienced financial hardship in recent years with the combination of recovering from failed development projects and the COVID-19 pandemic, and this grant will improve services to the city and surrounding area without creating additional burden on residents. The remainder the funding for this project will come from the fire department budget.

project_name: FY22 WRRF Improvements And Stormwater Combo Project
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to fund Phase II improvements at the Water Resource Recovery Facility (WRRF) and to improve the sanitary sewer and storm water system for East State Street. WRRF improvements include, secondary clarifier upgrades, installation of an odor control system, installation of a sludge drying gasification system. Biogas produced onsite will be the primary heat source for the drying system and operations buildings. The upgraded drying process is predicted to reduce yearly sludge solids output from 3,800 to 1,300 tons. An additional benefit of the new dryer system will be an end-product that is a Class A biosolid and or biochar, both can be recycled as opposed to being landfilled. These factors will significantly reduce trucking operations as sludge waste is now moved offsite to the Coventry Landfill. The Phase II improvements will be significant contributors to the citys 2030 Net Zero Goal. East State Street sanitary sewer and storm water improvements will reduce hydraulic overloading of the systems that can occur during wet weather events. This will reduce direct discharges to the North Branch of the Winooski River. The applicant is supplying additional funding and will receive funding from the Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation.

naics_industry_sector: Health Care and Social Assistance (62)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase equipment to allow the hospital to provide cutting edge and efficient care to patients in the age of COVID-19 and possible future pandemics. Equipment purchases from this grant will include a clinical communication and collaboration platform, an upgraded phone system, portable diagnostic and treatment equipment, portable beds and stretchers, lifts, smart beds, and cutting-edge diagnostic and treatment technologies. Like many hospitals, Brattleboro Memorial had to shift gears during the pandemic, providing treatment and testing and later immunization for COVID, while having to shut down many elective procedures that often provide a steady source of revenue. They also needed to adapt to new ways of providing care, such as expanded telemedicine services and greater distancing. The hospital has developed a comprehensive plan to update equipment throughout the hospital with these concerns in mind. More technologically advanced equipment will support telemedicine and shorten time required for treatments, requiring less close contact without sacrificing interaction with patients. Additionally, acquiring more portable equipment and lifts to assist in moving patients and equipment will mean patients have to move around the hospital less, can be quickly isolated and still receive treatment in place, and can be moved and monitored with less physical contact from providers, reducing risk of infection for both patients and providers. The remainder of the project will be funded by applicant contribution.

In addition, a composting building will be added to shield windrowed compost from the elements and improve composting efficiency. The compost operations improvements will significantly reduce landfilling of compostable material and also result in reduced greenhouse gas emissions associated with disposal of the noted materials. The applicant is supplying additional funding.

The Hub will serve as a new Welcome Center for the Kingdom Trail Association (KTA), a 100+ mile, year-round nonprofit trail network in Vermonts Caledonia and Essex counties. St. J Coworking will be a new coworking facility located in the downtown St. Johnsbury Welcome Center. This project has been planned for a number of years and has broad support at the local, state and national levels. The bridge is a significant historical landmark for Lyndon and one of a limited number of remaining covered bridges in the Northeast Kingdom (REAP Zone) of Vermont. The improvements will ensure the structure is in place for generations to come and will serve as a destination location for many from the local area as well as those visiting the Northeast Kingdom. With the future completion of the project, the town anticipates improving the surrounding trail access points and establishing a town-owned parking area and park location to serve as a recreation base for many types of outdoor activities.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to expand and renovate Turning Point Center of Central Vermonts new location in Barre, Vermont. project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to retrofit two properties owned by Black River Crossing, LLC, in Springfield, Vermont, with energy-efficiency upgrades and improvements. Springfield has experienced protracted economic hardship due to the closure of manufacturing, specifically tool and die machining. Since the mid-90s, the properties have been underutilized or vacant. One building still has an extremely inefficient oil-fired steam boiler as the primary source of heat. The goal of this project is to dramatically reduce the carbon footprint of these two marquee buildings that feature 8,000 square feet of prime downtown community retail and office space. By retrofitting both buildings with electric heat infrastructure and air handlers, all oil-heating systems can be removed. Substantial weatherization of the envelope is also necessary, including the total removal and replacement of old plate glass windows with historically sincere, energy-efficient windows, and substantially more insulation within exterior walls, allowing the buildings to operate in the cold Vermont climate with no oil or propane fuel demand. The project is estimated to save more than $17,600 annually, representing a 75-percent energy consumption reduction.
